Windows Autopilot Part 3: Testing & Troubleshooting

Test your Autopilot deployment, verify device enrollment, and fix common issues.

Congratulations! You‚Äôve set up your prerequisites, registered devices, and created deployment profiles. Now it‚Äôs time for the moment of truth ‚Äî actually testing your Autopilot deployment.

In this final part, we‚Äôll walk through what to expect, verify everything works, and troubleshoot any issues.

What Happens When a User First Turns On the Device

When a user unpacks a new Autopilot-configured PC and turns it on, here‚Äôs the journey they go through:

  1. Welcome Screen ‚Äî Language and keyboard selection
  2. Network Connection ‚Äî Connect to WiFi or Ethernet
  3. Sign In ‚Äî Enter their Azure AD credentials
  4. Enrollment ‚Äî Intune configures the device (this happens automatically!)
  5. Desktop ‚Äî User lands on a ready-to-use machine

Screenshot: OOBE welcome screen

Screenshot: User sign-in page

Screenshot: Enrollment in progress

Screenshot: Desktop ready

üí° Tip: This entire process typically takes 10-20 minutes depending on network speed and how many policies you deploy.

Step-by-Step: Test Your First Device

1. Reset the Device (If Previously Used)

If you‚Äôre testing with a device that‚Äôs been used before, you‚Äôll want to reset it first:

# On the test device, run as Administrator:
Windows + I ‚Üí Recovery ‚Üí Reset PC ‚Üí Remove everything ‚Üí Local reinstall

Or use the Intune Wipe command from Endpoint Manager if the device is already enrolled.

2. Go Through OOBE

Power on the device and walk through the out-of-box experience:

  1. Select your language and keyboard layout
  2. Connect to the internet (WiFi or Ethernet)
  3. When prompted, enter the Azure AD credentials of a test user
  4. Wait while enrollment completes
  5. You‚Äôre on the desktop!

3. Verify Device Appears in Intune

Now let‚Äôs confirm everything worked on the management side.

  1. Open the Microsoft Endpoint Manager admin center
  2. Go to Devices ‚Üí All devices
  3. Look for your test device

Screenshot: Device appearing in Intune

Click on the device to see its details:

Screenshot: Device details page

Check these things:

  • ‚úÖ Enrollment status: Should show ‚ÄúEnrolled‚Äù
  • ‚úÖ Last sync time: Should be recent
  • ‚úÖ Compliance status: Should be ‚ÄúCompliant‚Äù (or ‚ÄúNot evaluated‚Äù briefly after enrollment)
  • ‚úÖ Join type: Should show ‚ÄúAzure AD joined‚Äù

üí° Tip: If the device doesn‚Äôt appear immediately, click Sync to force a refresh.

Deploy Your First Policy

Now that your device is enrolled, let‚Äôs verify you can actually manage it by deploying a simple policy.

Example: Rename the Computer Automatically

Let‚Äôs create a configuration profile that renames the enrolled computer.

  1. In Endpoint Manager, go to Devices ‚Üí Configuration profiles
  2. Click Create profile
  3. Select Windows 10 and later
  4. Choose Settings catalog (or use a template)

Screenshot: Create configuration profile

For this example, let‚Äôs use the Device rename template:

  1. Search for ‚Äúdevice rename‚Äù in settings

  2. Configure the rename rule:

    • Name pattern: {first}-{serial} (e.g., ‚Äúzak-DELL1234‚Äù)
    • Action: Update

  3. Assign to your test device or group

Screenshot: Configure device rename policy

  1. Click Create

Trigger a Sync

After creating the policy, you need to push it to the device:

  1. Go to Devices ‚Üí All devices
  2. Select your test device
  3. Click Sync

üí° Tip: Wait 5-10 minutes for the policy to apply. The device checks in periodically.

Verify the Rename

On your test device:

  1. Open Settings ‚Üí System ‚Üí About
  2. Check if the device name has changed to your new pattern!

Common Issues & How to Fix Them

Don‚Äôt panic if things don‚Äôt work perfectly the first time. Here are the most common Autopilot issues and their solutions.

Issue: ‚ÄúProfile Not Found‚Äù Error

What you see: During OOBE, the device says it can‚Äôt find an Autopilot profile.

Cause: The profile hasn‚Äôt been assigned to the device or group.

Fix:

  1. Go to Devices ‚Üí Windows ‚Üí Autopilot deployment profiles
  2. Open your profile
  3. Click Assign
  4. Make sure the device or its group is selected

Screenshot: Profile assignment error

Issue: Enrollment Failed

What you see: ‚ÄúEnrollment failed‚Äù or similar error during setup.

Cause: Usually a license issue ‚Äî the user doesn‚Äôt have an Intune license.

Fix:

  1. Check the user‚Äôs license in Microsoft 365 Admin Center
  2. Ensure they have Intune or M365 Business Premium
  3. Assign the license if missing

Issue: Can‚Äôt Join Azure AD

What you see: Device can‚Äôt connect to Azure AD during enrollment.

Cause: Network issues or Azure AD settings.

Fix:

  1. Verify the device has internet access
  2. Check Devices ‚Üí Azure AD devices ‚Üí Device settings in Endpoint Manager
  3. Ensure ‚ÄúUsers may join devices to Azure AD‚Äù is enabled
  4. Check that the user isn‚Äôt hitting device limits

Issue: Device Not Appearing After Import

What you see: You imported the CSV but the device doesn‚Äôt show up anywhere.

Cause: The hardware hash might be incorrect or the import failed silently.

Fix:

  1. Go to Devices ‚Üí Windows ‚Üí Windows devices
  2. Check for import errors
  3. Re-run the PowerShell script and re-import
  4. Make sure the CSV format is correct (no extra headers or columns)

Issue: Policy Not Applying

What you see: You created a policy but it hasn‚Äôt reached the device.

Cause: Timing or assignment issues.

Fix:

  1. Check Device status in the policy details
  2. Verify the device is in the assigned group
  3. Click Sync on the device
  4. Wait ‚Äî it can take up to 24 hours but usually faster

üí° Tip: Most issues resolve by having the device sync or by restarting the device.

Next Steps: Where Do You Go From Here?

You‚Äôve completed the Autopilot basics! Here‚Äôs where to explore next:

1. Add More Devices

  • Register your organization‚Äôs real devices
  • Consider buying from OEMs who pre-register (less work!)

2. Explore Self-Deploying Mode

  • For kiosk, digital signage, or shared devices
  • No user login required ‚Äî device automatically enrolls

3. Set Up Device Groups

  • Create dynamic groups based on device attributes
  • Target policies more precisely

4. Configure Compliance Policies

  • Set requirements for what makes a device ‚Äúhealthy‚Äù
  • Block access if devices aren‚Äôt compliant

5. Application Deployment

  • Push apps automatically during enrollment
  • Configure required apps that install silently

Quick Recap

In this series, you learned:

  • ‚úÖ Part 1: Prerequisites, licenses, and account setup
  • ‚úÖ Part 2: Registering devices and creating deployment profiles
  • ‚úÖ Part 3: Testing deployments and troubleshooting common issues

You‚Äôre now ready to deploy Windows devices with Autopilot in your organization!

Have questions or run into issues? Drop a comment below and I‚Äôll help you figure it out.
